title: Erdős Problem #732: Block-Compatible Sequences
description: A sequence 1 < X₁ ≤ X₂ ≤ ... ≤ Xₘ ≤ n is block-compatible if there exists a pairwise balanced block design A₁, ..., Aₘ ⊆ {1, ..., n} with |Aᵢ| = Xᵢ. Question 1: Characterize block-compatible sequences. Question 2: Count them.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem in 1981. A pairwise balanced block design (PBD) partitions all pairs from {1,...,n} into blocks. The sequence of block sizes determines many properties. Alon proved the counting question, but characterization remains open.
overview.problemStatement: Call a sequence 1 < X₁ ≤ X₂ ≤ ... ≤ Xₘ ≤ n block-compatible if there is a pairwise balanced block design A₁,...,Aₘ ⊆ {1,...,n} with |Aᵢ| = Xᵢ. Q1: Are there necessary and sufficient conditions? Q2: Is there c > 0 such that there are ≥ exp(c·√n·log n) block-compatible sequences?
overview.proofStrategy: The pair-counting condition Σ C(Xᵢ,2) = C(n,2) is necessary but not sufficient. For counting, Erdős proved the upper bound and Alon proved the matching lower bound, resolving Q2 affirmatively.
keyInsights: Pair-counting is necessary: each pair must be covered exactly once
Pair-counting is NOT sufficient: some sequences satisfying it have no PBD
Erdős upper bound: B(n) ≤ exp(O(√n·log n))
Q2 is SOLVED, Q1 (characterization) remains OPEN

sections.title: Question 2 - Counting
sections.summary: Erdős's upper bound and Alon's lower bound establish B(n) ≈ 2^((1/2+o(1))√n·log n). Q2 is SOLVED.

sections.title: Summary
sections.summary: Complete summary: Q2 SOLVED by Alon, Q1 characterization remains OPEN.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #732 is PARTIALLY SOLVED. Question 2 (counting) is resolved by Alon's lower bound matching Erdős's upper bound. Question 1 (characterization of block-compatible sequences) remains open - the pair-counting condition is necessary but not sufficient.
conclusion.implications: The exponential count of block-compatible sequences suggests rich combinatorial structure in PBDs. The lack of a simple characterization indicates the problem's inherent complexity.
openQuestions: What are necessary and sufficient conditions for block-compatibility?
Can the asymptotic constant be determined exactly?
What is the structure of 'hard' sequences that satisfy pair-counting but aren't block-compatible?
